questions.title: Passage I
questions.article:
Torrent frogs (Staurois guttatus) can cling to wet sur­faces, even when the surfaces are at an angle of 90° (verti­cal) or greater. Researchers conducted 2 experiments to study how surface texture and water flow over the surface affects the clinging ability of S. guttatus.

Experiment 1
An apparatus was constructed with a transparent plat­form that could have different surface textures applied to it and that could be rotated 180°. A pump could direct water from a tank to flow over the platform (see Figure 1).

Then, in each of 9 trials (Trials 1一9), each of 10 S. guttatus (identical in size) was tested as follows:

1. The water flow rate was adjusted, a surface texture was applied to the platform, and the platform was rotated to a 10° angle.

2. A frog was placed on the platform.

3. The platform was rotated from 10° to 180° at a rate of 5° per sec.

4. The angle of detachment (angle at which the frog detached from the platform) was recorded.

The average angle of detachment was determined for each trial (see Table 1).


Experiment 2
Trial 1 of Experiment 1 was repeated, but with a camera attached to the underside of the platform. At spe­cific platform rotation angles during the trial, the camera was used to determine each frog's contact area (the surface of the frog that was in contact with the platform). in millimeters squared (mm2). The average contact area was determined for each angle (see Figure 2).


Table and figures adapted from T. Endlein et al., "Sticking Under Wet Condition: The Remarkable Attachment Abilities of the Torrent Frog, Staurois guttatus." @2013 by T. Endlein et al.
questions.question: 1. According to the results of Experiment 2, as the platform rotation angle was increased, the average contact area:

questions.question: 2. In Experiment 1, how many trials, in total, resulted in an average angle of detachment of 130° or less?

questions.title: Passage II
questions.article:
In aqueous solutions, vitamin C (C6H8O6) reacts with iodine (I2) according to the balanced chemical equation

C6H8O6 + I2 → C6H6O6 + 2HI

The amount of vitamin C in a solution can be determined by performing a titration. The titrant (a solution containing a known concentration of I2) is slowly added to the analyte (a solution containing a particular concentration of vitamin C), and a chemical reaction occurs. This process is monitored by adding an indicator to the analyte. The indi­cator is a colorless starch solution that changes to a dark color by reacting with I2 when no more vitamin C remains, signaling the end of the titration.

Students performed titrations to determine the amount of vitamin C in 4 different types of pulp-free juice.

Experiment 1
A 0.20 mg/mL vitamin C solution was prepared. A 1.0 mL sample of the solution was placed into a vial, and 1 drop of indicator was added to the vial. Drops of the I2 solution were then added to the vial until the indicator changed to a dark color. The procedure was repeated for solutions of 0.40, 0.60, 0.80, and 1.0 mg/mL of vitamin C (see Figure 1) .


Experiment 2
A 1.0 mL sample of lime juice was placed into a vial, and 1 drop of indicator was added to the vial. Drops of the I2 solution were added to the vial until the lime juice solu­tion changed to a dark color. This procedure was repeated for 3 other juices (see Table 1).


Figure and label adapted from R. Ballentine, "Determination of Ascorbic Acid in Citrus Fruit Juices." @ 1941 by the American Chemical Society.
questions.question: 8. Consider the steps performed in Experiment 2 that are listed below.1.	Stop adding titrant when the indicator changes to a dark color.2.	Add starch indicator to vial.3. 	Place juice sample into vial.4.	Slowly add drops of titrant.These steps were performed in what sequence?

Figure and label adapted from R. Ballentine, "Determination of Ascorbic Acid in Citrus Fruit Juices." @ 1941 by the American Chemical Society.
questions.question: 9. Based on the results of Experiments 1 and 2, which of the juices that were tested contained the greatest concentration of vitamin C ?

Based on the results of Experiment 1, what is the mini­mum number of drops of the I2 solution that would have been required to change the indicator in the apple juice solution to a dark color?

questions.title: Passage Ill
questions.article: All known exoplanets (planets in orbit about stars other than the Sun) are too distant from Earth to be studied in detail, so mathematical models have been developed to help predict their properties. Figures 1-3 each show how a different property varies with altitude above the surface of Earth and above the surfaces of 2 hypothetical exoplanets: Planet X and Planet Y. Figure 1 shows how atmospheric temperature, T (in kelvins, K), varies; Figure 2 shows how atmospheric pressure, how P (in atmospheres, atm), varies; and Figure 3 shows how gravitational field strength, g (in newtons per kilogram, N/kg), varies.
questions.question: 15. According to Figure 1, at approximately what altitude above their respective surfaces do Planets X and Y have the same atmospheric temperature, and what is that temperature?

questions.question: 16. According to Figure 2, which of the following graphs best represents the altitude above the surface of Earth, of Planet X, and of Planet Y at which P = 0.3 atm ?

questions.question: 17. Atmospheric density and P are directly proportional to each other. Based on Figure 2, which planet more likely has the more dense atmosphere at an altitude of 5 km, Earth or Planet Y ?

choices.A: Earth; at an altitude of 5 km, P for Earth is less than P for Planet Y.
choices.B: Earth; at an altitude of 5 km, P for Earth is greater than P for Planet Y.
choices.C: Planet Y; at an altitude of 5 km, P for Planet Y is less than P for Earth.
choices.D: Planet Y; at an altitude of 5 km, P for Planet Y is greater than P for Earth.

questions.question: 18. At the surface of a planet, g is given by the equationwhere G is a constant, M is the planet's mass, and R is the planet's radius. Assume that Earth, Planet X. and Planet Y have equal radii. Based on Figure 3, which planet has the greatest mass?

choices.D: Cannot be determined from the given information

questions.question: 19. Based on Figure 1, is the average kinetic energy of the gas particles in Earth's atmosphere more likely greater at an altitude of 40 km or 80 km ?

choices.A: 40 km, because the average  kinetic energy of gas particles is directly proportional to gas temperature.
choices.B: 40 km,  because the average kinetic energy of gas particles is inversely proportional to gas temperature.
choices.C: 80 km,  because the average kinetic energy of gas particles is directly proportional to gas temperature.
choices.D: 80 km,  because the average kinetic energy of gas particles is inversely proportional to gas temperature.

questions.question: 20. The gravitational field strength at the surface of Planet X is approximately what percent of the gravitational field strength at the surface of Earth？

questions.title: Passage IV
questions.article:
As sound waves travel through seawater, some of their energy is absorbed by the seawater. This sound absorption depends on several factors, including the pH of the water, the depth below the water's surface at which the sound waves travel, the frequency of the sound waves, the water temperature, and the water's salinity (concentration of dis­solved salts in the water). Figures 1, 2, and 3 show一under the given conditions, respectively一how sound absorption (in decibels per kilometer, dB/km) varies with frequency (in kilohertz, kHz), temperature (in °C), and salinity (in parts per thousand, ppt; 1 ppt = 1 g/kg).




Figures adapted from Michael A. Ainslie and James G. McColm, "A Simplified Formula for Viscous and Chemical Absorption in Sea Water." @ 1998 by Acoustical Society of America.
questions.question: 21. According to Figure 2, at which of the following water temperatures is the sound absorption by the seawater closest to 0.67 dB/km？

questions.question: 23. Suppose that, under the conditions given in Figure 3, sound waves travel a distance of 1 km from a source to a detector. Based on Figure 3, the least energy would be absorbed from the sound waves by the seawater if it has which of the following salinities?

questions.question: 24. Suppose sound absorption by seawater is measured under the conditions given in Figure 2, except that the frequency of the sound waves is 16 kHz. Based on Fig­ures 1 and 2, if the temperature of the seawater is 3°C, will the sound absorption more likely be less than 1.20 dB/km or greater than 1.20 dB/km ?

choices.A: Less than 1.20 dB/km, because sound absorption decreases as frequency decreases.
choices.B: Less than 1.20 dB/km, because sound absorption decreases as frequency increases.
choices.C: Greater than 1.20 dB/km, because sound absorp­tion increases as frequency decreases.
choices.D: Greater than 1.20 dB/km, because sound absorption increases as frequency increases.

questions.title: Passage IV

questions.question: 25. As the acidity o f seawater increases, sound absorption decreases. Based on Figure 2, at a depth of 0.05 km, a salinity of 35 ppt, a frequency of 10 kHz, a water tem­perature of 20°C, and a pH of 6.0, is the sound absorp­tion less than 0.75 dB/km or greater than 0.75 dB/km?

choices.A: Less than 0.75 dB/km, because seawater at pH = 6.0 is less acidic than seawater at pH = 8.0.
choices.B: Less than 0.75 dB/km, because seawater at pH = 6.0 is more acidic than seawater at pH = 8.0.
choices.C: Greater than 0.75 dB/km, because seawater at pH = 6.0 is less acidic than seawater at pH = 8.0.
choices.D: Greater than 0.75 dB/km, because seawater at pH = 6. 0 is more acidic than seawater at pH = 8.0.

questions.question: 26. Consider in Figure 1 how sound absorption changes as the frequency of the sound waves increases. As the wavelength (NOT frequency) of the sound waves increases, does sound absorption increase or decrease?

choices.A: Increase; as frequency increases, wavelength increases.
choices.B: Increase; as frequency increases, wavelength decreases.
choices.C: Decrease; as frequency increases, wavelength mcreases.
choices.D: Decrease; as frequency increases, wavelength decreases.

questions.title: Passage V
questions.article:
Giant puffball mushrooms (GPMs) have belowground and aboveground structures. Below ground, tubelike threads called hyphae extend throughout the soil. Aboveground, the visible portion of the GPM is referred to as a basidiocarp. When some GPMs are disrupted, such as when they are stepped on by an animal, a cloud of particles resem­bling smoke is released from the basidiocarp. Two students discuss the function of the hyphae and basidiocarps in GPMs and also discuss the contents of the cloud of parti­cles released when the basidiocarp is disrupted.

Student 1
The basidiocarps of GPMs are reproductive structures. When cells in the basidiocarp are mature, they produce, by meiosis, cells called spores. The spores are stored directly below the surface of the basidiocarp until the basidiocarp is disrupted. After release, a spore may settle in the soil, ger­minate, and then form a new hypha. When a newly formed hypha meets another newly formed hypha, they fuse and then produce a new basidiocarp. Young basidiocarps do not yet contain spores and thus do not produce a cloud of parti­cles when disrupted.

The hyphae of a GPM acquire nutrients for the organ­ism from organic matter in the soil. The nutrients are then transported to feed the aboveground structure.

Student 2
The hyphae of GPMs are reproductive structures, sim­ilar to the roots of some plants that reproduce asexually. To produce a new GPM, the hyphae grow away from the parental GPM to another location in the soil. Once the hyphae have grown away from the parental GPM, the hyphae produce a new basidiocarp. After the new basidio­carp has formed, the newly grown hypbae separate from the parental hyphae.

Like the leaves of plants, the basidiocarps of GPMs produce energy for the organisms through the process of photosynthesis. Basidiocarps also function as deterrents to predators by releasing a cloud of particles comaining toxins when disrupted. Young GPMs do not yet produce toxins and are thus unable to release a cloud of particles.
questions.question: 27. According to Student 1 and Student 2, respectively, what is the main functional component contained in the cloud of particles from a disrupted basidiocarp?

questions.question: 28. Student 1 implies that the basidiocarps of some GPMs do not release a cloud of particles when disrupted because the:

choices.A: cells of the basidiocarp have not yet made toxins.
choices.B: cells of the basidiocarp have not yet become repro­ductively mature.
choices.C: basidiocarp has not yet separated from the parental GPM.
choices.D: basidiocarp has not yet produced enough energy for the GPM.

questions.question: 33. Based on Student 2's discussion, why do newly formed hyphae separate from parental hyphae after, rather than before, the formation of a new basidiocarp?

choices.A: The basidiocarp of a GPM provides energy for other organisms.
choices.B: The basidiocarp of a GPM provides energy for the GPM.
choices.C: The hyphae of a GPM provide energy for other organisms.
choices.D: The hyphae of a GPM provide energy for the GPM.

questions.title: Passage VI
questions.article:
A semiconductor is a substance whose electrical prop­erties can be fine-tuned by doping (replacing some of the substance's atoms with atoms of another substance). Silicon is one example of a semiconductor. A scientist per­formed 2 experiments to study the electrical resistance, R, of silicon wafers (thin blocks) that had been doped.

Experiment 1
The scientist placed 15 silicon wafers into a tempera­ture-controlled chamber. The length and width of each wafer was 10.95 mm, and the thickness of each wafer was 0.95 mm. One wafer was pure silicon, 7 of the wafers had been doped with boron atoms, and 7 of the wafers had been doped with arsenic atoms. Each of the boron-doped wafers and each of the arsenic-doped wafers had a different doping concentration, Nd (the number of doping atoms per cubic centimeter, atoms/cm³). The scientist then connected each wafer to a separate ohmmeter (a device that measures R). Figure 1 shows this apparatus; for clarity only 1 wafer is shown connected.


The scientist set the temperature, T, of the chamber at 300 kelvins (K). Then, after the wafers had been in the chamber for 30 min, she measured R (in ohms, Ω) for each wafer. Figure 2 shows R for the doped wafers; R for the pure silicon wafer was 3.2 × 107Ω.


Experiment 2
The scientist removed each wafer from the chamber except for the two having Nd = 1016 atoms/cm3 . She measured R for these 2 wafers at various temperatures, waiting 30 min between setting T and measuring R (see Figure 3).


Figures 2 and 3 adapted from Narain D. Arora, John R. Hauser, and David J. Roulston, "Electron and Hole Mobilities in Silicon as a Function of Concentration and Temperature." @ 1982 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
questions.question: 34. Suppose that in Experiment 2 the scientist had measured a resistance of 22  for the boron-doped wafer. The temperature of the wafer at the time of this measurement would most likely hove been:

questions.question: 36.  Based on the results of Experiments 1 and 2, which of the following statements best summarize the relation-ship between R and Nd and the relationship between R and T ? R increased as:

choices.A: Nd increased and as T increased.
choices.B: Nd increased and as T decreased.
choices.C: Nd decreased and as T increased.
choices.D: Nd decreased and as T decreased.

questions.question: 37. Did the scientist investigate whether the resistance of a doped wafer is affected by the wafer's dimensions?

choices.A: Yes; the wafers that were tested had different dimensions.
choices.B: Yes; the wafers that were tested had the same dimensions.
choices.C: No; the wafers that were tested had different dimensions.
choices.D: No; the wafers that were tested had the same dimensions.

Silicon is one example of a semiconductor. A scientist per­formed 2 experiments to study the electrical resistance, R, of silicon wafers (thin blocks) that had been doped.

Experiment 1
The scientist placed 15 silicon wafers into a tempera­ture-controlled chamber. The length and width of each wafer was 10.95 mm, and the thickness of each wafer was 0.95 mm. One wafer was pure silicon, 7 of the wafers had been doped with boron atoms, and 7 of the wafers had been doped with arsenic atoms. Each of the boron-doped wafers and each of the arsenic-doped wafers had a different doping concentration, Nd (the number of doping atoms per cubic centimeter, atoms/cm³). The scientist then connected each wafer to a separate ohmmeter (a device that measures R). Figure 1 shows this apparatus; for clarity only 1 wafer is shown connected.


The scientist set the temperature, T, of the chamber at 300 kelvins (K). Then, after the wafers had been in the chamber for 30 min, she measured R (in ohms, Ω) for each wafer. Figure 2 shows R for the doped wafers; R for the pure silicon wafer was 3.2 × 107Ω.


Experiment 2
The scientist removed each wafer from the chamber except for the two having Nd = 1016 atoms/cm3 . She measured R for these 2 wafers at various temperatures, waiting 30 min between setting T and measuring R (see Figure 3).


Figures 2 and 3 adapted from Narain D. Arora, John R. Hauser, and David J. Roulston, "Electron and Hole Mobilities in Silicon as a Function of Concentration and Temperature." @ 1982 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
questions.question: 38. In Experiments 1 and 2, the scientist most likely waited between setting T and measuring R to ensure that the:

choices.A: wafers were in thermal equilibrium with the chamber.
choices.B: ohmmeters were not in thermal equilibrium with the chamber.
choices.C: chamber was in thermal equilibrium with the greater laboratory environment.
choices.D: doping atoms within each wafer were not in thermal equilibrium with the chamber.

questions.title: Passage VI
questions.article:
A semiconductor is a substance whose electrical prop­erties can be fine-tuned by doping (replacing some of the substance's atoms with atoms of another substance). Silicon is one example of a semiconductor. A scientist per­formed 2 experiments to study the electrical resistance, R, of silicon wafers (thin blocks) that had been doped.

Experiment 1
The scientist placed 15 silicon wafers into a tempera­ture-controlled chamber. The length and width of each wafer was 10.95 mm, and the thickness of each wafer was 0.95 mm. One wafer was pure silicon, 7 of the wafers had been doped with boron atoms, and 7 of the wafers had been doped with arsenic atoms. Each of the boron-doped wafers and each of the arsenic-doped wafers had a different doping concentration, Nd (the number of doping atoms per cubic centimeter, atoms/cm³). The scientist then connected each wafer to a separate ohmmeter (a device that measures R). Figure 1 shows this apparatus; for clarity only 1 wafer is shown connected.


The scientist set the temperature, T, of the chamber at 300 kelvins (K). Then, after the wafers had been in the chamber for 30 min, she measured R (in ohms, Ω) for each wafer. Figure 2 shows R for the doped wafers; R for the pure silicon wafer was 3.2 × 107Ω.


Experiment 2
The scientist removed each wafer from the chamber except for the two having Nd = 1016 atoms/cm3 . She measured R for these 2 wafers at various temperatures, waiting 30 min between setting T and measuring R (see Figure 3).


Figures 2 and 3 adapted from Narain D. Arora, John R. Hauser, and David J. Roulston, "Electron and Hole Mobilities in Silicon as a Function of Concentration and Temperature." @ 1982 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
questions.question: 39. Based on the results of Experiment 1, the ohmmeter shown in Figure 1 is most likely connected to the wafer doped with which type of atoms and at what doping concentration?

choices.A: type of doping atoms: boron ;    Nd (atoms/cm3): 1015
choices.B: type of doping atoms: boron ;    Nd (atoms/cm3): 1016
choices.C: type of doping atoms: arsenic ;    Nd (atoms/cm3): 1015
choices.D: type of doping atoms: arsenic ;    Nd (atoms/cm3): 1016

questions.title: Passage VI
questions.article:
A semiconductor is a substance whose electrical prop­erties can be fine-tuned by doping (replacing some of the substance's atoms with atoms of another substance). Silicon is one example of a semiconductor. A scientist per­formed 2 experiments to study the electrical resistance, R, of silicon wafers (thin blocks) that had been doped.

Experiment 1
The scientist placed 15 silicon wafers into a tempera­ture-controlled chamber. The length and width of each wafer was 10.95 mm, and the thickness of each wafer was 0.95 mm. One wafer was pure silicon, 7 of the wafers had been doped with boron atoms, and 7 of the wafers had been doped with arsenic atoms. The scientist set the temperature, T, of the chamber at 300 kelvins (K). Then, after the wafers had been in the chamber for 30 min, she measured R (in ohms, Ω) for each wafer. Figure 2 shows R for the doped wafers; R for the pure silicon wafer was 3.2 × 107Ω.

The scientist removed each wafer from the chamber except for the two having Nd = 1016 atoms/cm3 . She measured R for these 2 wafers at various temperatures, waiting 30 min between setting T and measuring R (see Figure 3).


Figures 2 and 3 adapted from Narain D. Arora, John R. Hauser, and David J. Roulston, "Electron and Hole Mobilities in Silicon as a Function of Concentration and Temperature." @ 1982 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
questions.question: 40. Based on the value of R for the pure silicon wafer and the data in Figure 2, does replacing some of the silicon atoms in a silicon wafer with doping atoms make the wafer a better conductor or a better insulator?

choices.A: A better conductor, because the resistance of each doped wafer was less than that of the pure silicon wafer.
choices.B: A better conductor, because the resistance of each doped wafer was greater than than of the pure sili­con wafer.
choices.C: A better insulator, because the resistance of each doped wafer was less than that of the pure silicon wafer.
choices.D: A better insulator, because the resistance of each doped wafer was greater than that of the pure sili­con wafer.
